issues.title: References needed for some cited related work
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: The draft includes "Further work on a similar scheme has also been progressed at the FIDO Alliance and W3C. Similarly Intel released (EPID) which provides a solution to remote hardware attestation for Intel Software Guard Extension (SGX) enabled environments."  IETF style guidelines say that if we're citing work, we should provide references to it.

issues.title: Rename draft to conform to IETF naming conventions
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body:
To submit to the COSE working group, the draft name must be of the form `draft-<lastname>-cose-<draftname>`.  I'd suggest the identifier `draft-looker-cose-bls-curves-representations` or something similar.

Note that both the filename and the draft name in the markdown (which is currently `draft-looker-bls-jose-cose-00`) need to be changed.

comments.author: tplooker
comments.body: Fixed in ed6cd3ad47070a4a6e793717837272e404710ef2

issues.title: Are the JOSE registrations missing "Key Type: OKP"?
issues.author: quartzjer
issues.body: It's in each of the COSE registrations, should it be in the JOSE ones too?

comments.author: tplooker
comments.body: If by registration you mean the IANA section for each then the reason they key type is absent in the JOSE registrations is that it is not required for that IANA registry [see here](https://www.iana.org/assignments/jose/jose.xhtml#web-key-elliptic-curve), whereas with COSE the key type forms part of the registration [see here](https://www.iana.org/assignments/cose/cose.xhtml#elliptic-curves)

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: @tplooker's analysis of the issue is correct.

issues.title: Key identifier?
issues.author: quartzjer
issues.body:
I'm posing this as a question and not a direct suggestion.

The key identifiers are specifically for only one subgroup (the `G1` on `Bls48581G1 ` for example) on the defined pairing curve, and in practice an implementation will use that single group identifier to first identify the pairing curve itself, caring only about the `Bls48581` prefix.  Would it make sense to add a separator character such as `_`, `-`, or `+` like in other JOSE/COSE identifiers?

In fact, one could argue that `Bls48581` is technically the curve name and the group could be identified via a separate element, but that's being rather pedantic :)

comments.author: tplooker
comments.body:
> The key identifiers are specifically for only one subgroup (the G1 on Bls48581G1 for example) on the defined pairing curve, and in practice an implementation will use that single group identifier to first identify the pairing curve itself, caring only about the Bls48581 prefix. Would it make sense to add a separator character such as _, -, or + like in other JOSE/COSE identifiers?

Yes this could be a good suggestion if we believe implementations will benefit from being able to partially parse the `crv` value to know the underlying curve involved is and then further process OR use another field to establish what sub-group is being used. Im unsure however how common that behaviour may be?

issues.title: Add code point for 48 bytes BLS12-381 signatures
issues.author: emanjon
issues.body:
As discussed at IETF 116 there are several reasons to also register a signature algorithm. BLS signatures do not have to be used with aggregations. They can also be used as a replacement for ordinary ECDSA signatures. The benefit with a BLS12-381 signatures are that they are 48 bytes instead of the 64 bytes for ECDSA and EdDSA. This would be a nice addition to COSE.

Other people agreed and stated that registering a signature should be done just to make the document complete and useful in it self.

One use case for 48 bytes BLS12-381 signatures is Group OSCORE. With 48 bytes signatures you could in quite many cases get away with sending one frame less which is a big win.

comments.author: OR13
comments.body:
I still support this idea : )

How hard would it be to add this?

Seems we need to register an "alg" and define the structure of the signature.

Similar to https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc8812.html#name-ecdsa-signature-with-secp25

@emanjon any proposals for the "alg" name?

... "BLS12" ?

comments.author: OR13
comments.body: Assuming it is possible, I can generate some test vectors from https://github.com/paulmillr/noble-bls12-381

comments.author: selfissued
comments.body: @tplooker, should we discuss this at IETF 119?

issues.title: Bls should be BLS
issues.author: selfissued
issues.body: All of the letters b l s should be capitalized, since they are initials for people's names.  @dwaite pointed this out to me during a JWP call.

comments.author: dwaite
comments.body: Any progress on this? I assume the S should be capitalized since it is a person's name (Scott)

pulls.title: Update intro and sec considerations
pulls.author: tplooker
pulls.body: Attempts to make it more apparent what the immediate application of standardizing these cryptographic keys is useful for, also adds a section that notes implementers should be aware of using the keys within various algorithms

reviews.author: selfissued
reviews.body: Please merge when ready after applying the single grammatical correction that I suggested in my comment.

comments.body: a particular algorithm -> particular algorithms.

```suggestion
Furthermore, because this specification only defines the cryptographic key representations and not the usage of these keys with specific algorithms, implementers should be aware to follow any guidance that may be provided around appropriate usage of the keys and or additional steps that may be required to validate the keys within the context of particular algorithms.
```

reviews.author: selfissued
reviews.body:
There should be a Document History appendix, with this content:

-00

- Created draft-ietf-cose-bls-key-representations-00 from draft-looker-cose-bls-key-representations-00 following working group adoption.

(See https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-oauth-jwk-thumbprint-uri-03.html#name-document-history for an example of such a Document History section.)

pulls.title: Add jwk example for BLS12-381 curve
pulls.author: tplooker

comments.body: While it is possible to share a common private key and generate two public keys across the two sub-groups this violates common practise around key reusage, I will update the example to have distinct key pairs. @selfissued, do you think we should offer a security consideration about this case, I'm not aware of any particular insecurity that this would create, however it would algorithm dependent.
I think it's worth mentioning the tradeoffs, at least at the level you're describing them in this comment.  It may cause people who know more than we do to weigh in.

pulls.title: Add jwk examples
pulls.author: BasileiosKal
pulls.body: 2 JWK examples for each subgroup of Bls12381

comments.body: The crv value is case sensitive
Fixed.
It might be worth a comment saying that these - on purpose - represent private keys.  Otherwise people might question the inclusion of "d".
Thanks! Added a note in the beginning of the Section.

```suggestion
The following examples showcase JWKs for both the G1 and G2 subgroups of the Bls12381 curve. Note, the examples also include the corresponding private key, expressed through the inclusion of the “d” parameter.
```

```suggestion
An example JWK for the Bls12381 curve where the public key is in the G1 subgroup.
```

```suggestion
Another example of a different JWK for the Bls12381 curve where the public key is in the G1 subgroup.
```

```suggestion
```

```

Why are the x and d values of different lengths?  That seems suspicious to me.

If it's omitting leading zeros, for instance, that's not what JWKs do.

The length of the private key is given by the field size while the compressed representation of the public key (using the x parameter) is derived from the group size, I'll add some text to clarify this.
